intro: Acaena sarmentosa var. longiuscula, commonly known as the slender mat grass, is a low-growing, mat-forming shrub native to New Zealand. It features small, spiny fruits that are adapted for dispersal by animals. The plant has wiry, persistent stems that root at the nodes, allowing it to spread vegetatively. Its leaves are narrow and hairy, often with a bluish-gray coloration. This species thrives in coastal and subalpine environments, where it plays a role in stabilizing soil and providing habitat for native wildlife.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acaena sarmentosa var. longiuscula is primarily native to New Zealand. It is found in the South Island, particularly in the Canterbury and Otago regions. This plant typically grows in open, sunny habitats such as grasslands and rocky areas. It is well adapted to the dry and temperate climate of these regions. The variety is known for its low-growing habit and distinctive yellow flowers.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acaena sarmentosa var. longiuscula was mainly introduced to New Zealand. It was brought there as part of the European colonization efforts in the 19th century. This plant has since become naturalized in various regions of the country. It is commonly found in disturbed soils and along roadsides. Its introduction has had both ecological and agricultural impacts in New Zealand.
